Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Early Psychosocial Intervention in Orthopaedic Trauma Patients

Participants.evidence: Participants were 112 orthopaedic trauma patients aged 18-85 years, excluding those with traumatic brain injury, communication barriers, or severe psychiatric conditions.

Intervention.evidence: Integrative care included usual trauma care plus psychosocial and movement strategies.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate whether an early psychosocial intervention improves physical function outcomes compared to usual care.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was physical function, measured objectively and subjectively at baseline, 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were randomised to integrative care (n=56) or usual care (n=56) using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was per-protocol with 99 participants (integrative care n=50, usual care n=49).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Elbow flexion was 20° ± 10° greater in the integrative care group (p=0.05).
